title: Get Out
consensus: Funny, scary, and thought-provoking,  seamlessly weaves its trenchant social critiques into a brilliantly effective and entertaining horror/comedy thrill ride.

title: Columbus
consensus: Wonderfully acted and artfully composed,  balances the clean lines of architecture against the messiness of love, with tenderly moving results.

title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni)
consensus: offers a unique ground-level perspective on an oft-dramatized period in history, further distinguished by beautiful hand-drawn animation.

title: The Shape of Water
consensus: finds Guillermo del Toro at his visually distinctive best -- and matched by an emotionally absorbing story brought to life by a stellar Sally Hawkins performance.

title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute)
consensus: Moving without resorting to melodrama,  offers an engrossing look at a pivotal period in history that lingers long after the closing credits roll.

title: A Ghost Story
consensus: deftly manages its ambitious themes through an inventive, artful, and ultimately poignant exploration of love and loss.

title: Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri
consensus: deftly balances black comedy against searing drama -- and draws unforgettable performances from its veteran cast along the way.

title: Thor: Ragnarok
consensus: Exciting, funny, and above all fun,  is a colorful cosmic adventure that sets a new standard for its franchise -- and the rest of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

title: Graduation (Bacalaureat)
consensus: marks yet another well-written and powerfully acted look at morality and societal decay from writer-director Cristian Mungiu.

title: The Red Turtle (La tortue rouge)
consensus: adds to Studio Ghibli's estimable legacy with a beautifully animated effort whose deceptively simple story boasts narrative layers as richly absorbing as its lovely visuals.

title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku)
consensus: crosses cultural lines to offer timeless observations about parental responsibilities, personal bonds, and the capacity for forgiveness.

title: I, Daniel Blake
consensus: marks yet another well-told chapter in director Ken Loach's powerfully populist filmography.

title: The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)
consensus: observes the family dynamic through writer-director Noah Baumbach's bittersweet lens and the impressive efforts of a remarkable cast.

title: The Beguiled
consensus: adds just enough extra depth to its source material to set itself apart, and director Sofia Coppola's restrained touch is enlivened by strong performances from the cast.

title: Your Name. (Kimi No Na Wa.)
consensus: As beautifully animated as it is emotionally satisfying,  adds another outstanding chapter to writer-director Makoto Shinkai's filmography.

title: Kong: Skull Island
consensus: Offering exhilarating eye candy, solid acting, and a fast-paced story,  earns its spot in the movie monster's mythos without ever matching up to the classic original.

title: Menashe
consensus: offers an intriguing look at a culture whose unfamiliarity to many viewers will be rendered irrelevant by the story's universally affecting themes and thoughtful approach.

title: Ingrid Goes West
consensus: Led by strong performances from Aubrey Plaza and Elizabeth Olsen,  delivers smart, topical humor underlined by timely social observations.

title: First They Killed My Father
consensus: tackles its subject matter with grace, skill, and empathy, offering a ground-level look at historic atrocities that resonates beyond its story's borders.

title: My Scientology Movie
consensus: offers a personal perspective on the controversial religion whose lack of investigative depth is more than balanced out by its sense of humor and all-around entertainment value.

title: David Lynch: The Art Life
consensus: offers a look at the director's life and craft whose unusual approach is in keeping with its subject's singularly strange aesthetic.

title: Professor Marston & The Wonder Women
consensus: winds a lasso of cinematic truth around a fascinating fact-based tale with strong performances from its three stars.

title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore.
consensus: transcends its unwieldy title to offer timely, intoxicatingly dark observations on gender dynamics and social norms in modern America.

title: Gerald's Game
consensus: Carla Gugino carries 's small-scale suspense with a career-defining performance.

title: Novitiate
consensus: Led by a gripping performance from Melissa Leo,  grapples uncompromisingly -- and ultimately compellingly -- with questions of faith and feminism.

title: Hounds of Love
consensus: Smartly constructed and powerfully acted,  satisfies as a psychological thriller with a few nasty surprises -- and marks writer-director Ben Young as a promising talent.

title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants)
consensus: With a tidy plot, clean animation, and humor that fits its source material snugly,  is entertainment that won't drive a wedge between family members.

title: Detroit
consensus: delivers a gut-wrenching -- and essential -- dramatization of a tragic chapter from America's past that draws distressing parallels to the present.

title: The Founder
consensus: puts Michael Keaton's magnetic performance at the center of a smart, satisfying biopic that traces the rise of one of America's most influential businessmen -- and the birth of one of its most far-reaching industries.

title: Marjorie Prime
consensus: Intimate in setting yet ambitious in scope, the beautifully acted  poses thought-provoking questions about memory, humanity, and love.

title: Land of Mine (Under Sandet)
consensus: uses an oft-forgotten chapter from the aftermath of World War II to tell a hard-hitting story whose period setting belies its timeless observations about bloodshed and forgiveness.

title: Maudie
consensus: 's talented cast -- particularly Sally Hawkins in the title role -- breathe much-needed depth into a story that only skims the surface of a fascinating life and talent.

title: Battle of the Sexes
consensus: turns real-life events into a crowd-pleasing, well-acted dramedy that ably entertains while smartly serving up a volley of present-day parallels.

title: Obit
consensus: shines an entertaining -- and overdue -- spotlight on an engaging group of people whose singular craft is too often taken for granted.

title: Their Finest
consensus: Carried along by a winning performance from Gemma Arterton,  smoothly combines comedy and wartime drama to crowd-pleasing effect.

title: Okja
consensus: sees Bong Joon-ho continuing to create defiantly eclectic entertainment -- and still hitting more than enough of his narrative targets in the midst of a tricky tonal juggling act.

title: Abacus: Small Enough to Jail
consensus: transcends its less-than-dramatic trappings to present a gripping real-life legal thriller with far-reaching implications.

title: Gook
consensus: From its confrontational title to its striking cinematography, this raw cinematic gem uncompromisingly proves writer/director/actor Justin Chon is a filmmaker to watch.

title: Only the Brave
consensus: 's impressive veteran cast and affecting fact-based story add up to a no-frills drama that's just as stolidly powerful as the real-life heroes it honors.

title: All This Panic
consensus: offers an unvarnished look at the lives of young American women whose less compelling moments are more than balanced out by documentarian Jenny Gage's empathetic approach.

title: Brawl in Cell Block 99
consensus: rides a committed Vince Vaughn performance into the brutally violent -- and undeniably entertaining -- depths of prison-set grindhouse genre fare.

title: Silence
consensus: ends Martin Scorsese's decades-long creative quest with a thoughtful, emotionally resonant look at spirituality and human nature that stands among the director's finest works.

title: Girls Trip
consensus: is the rare R-rated comedy that pushes boundaries to truly comedic effect -- and anchors its laughs in compelling characters brought to life by a brilliantly assembled cast.

title: Human Flow
consensus: Epic in scope yet clear-eyed and intimate,  offers a singularly expansive -- and sobering -- perspective on the global refugee crisis.

title: Good Time
consensus: A visual treat filled out by consistently stellar work from Robert Pattinson,  is a singularly distinctive crime drama offering far more than the usual genre thrills.

title: Mudbound
consensus: offers a well-acted, finely detailed snapshot of American history whose scenes of rural class struggle resonate far beyond their period setting.

title: Lady Macbeth
consensus: flashes some surprising toughness beneath its period exterior, bolstered by a mesmerizing -- and unforgiving -- central performance by Florence Pugh.

title: The Lost City of Z
consensus: 's stately pace and visual grandeur hearken back to classic exploration epics, and Charlie Hunnam turns in a masterful performance as its complex protagonist.

title: The Women's Balcony (Ismach Hatani)
consensus: With rich characters and a thoughtful approach to timely themes,  tackles complicated subjects with intelligence, compassion, and wit.

title: Raw
consensus: 's lurid violence and sexuality live up to its title, but they're anchored with an immersive atmosphere and deep symbolism that linger long after the provocative visuals fade.

title: Wind River
consensus: lures viewers into a character-driven mystery with smart writing, a strong cast, and a skillfully rendered setting that delivers the bitter chill promised by its title.

title: It
consensus: Well-acted and fiendishly frightening with an emotionally affecting story at its core,  amplifies the horror in Stephen King's classic story without losing touch with its heart.

title: 20th Century Women
consensus: offers Annette Bening a too-rare opportunity to shine in a leading role -- and marks another assured step forward for writer-director Mike Mills.

title: Prevenge
consensus: As ambitious as it is daringly transgressive,  should thrill fans of pitch-black horror-comedy -- and open untold opportunities for writer/director/star Alice Lowe.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2
consensus: 's action-packed plot, dazzling visuals, and irreverent humor add up to a sequel that's almost as fun -- if not quite as thrillingly fresh -- as its predecessor.

title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography
consensus: offers an intriguing glimpse at a distinctive artist's work that's as warmly engaging as its subject.

title: The Death of Stalin
consensus: finds director/co-writer Arnando Iannucci in riotous form, bringing his scabrous political humor to bear on a chapter in history with painfully timely parallels.

title: It Comes At Night
consensus: makes lethally effective use of its bare-bones trappings while proving once again that what's left unseen can be just as horrifying as anything on the screen.

title: A Monster Calls
consensus: deftly balances dark themes and fantastical elements to deliver an engrossing and uncommonly moving entry in the crowded coming-of-age genre.

title: Step
consensus: tells an irresistibly crowd-pleasing story in a thoroughly absorbing way -- and while smartly incorporating a variety of timely themes.

title: American Made
consensus: 's fast-and-loose attitude with its real-life story mirrors the cavalier -- and delightfully watchable -- energy Tom Cruise gives off in the leading role.

title: John Wick: Chapter 2
consensus: does what a sequel should -- which in this case means doubling down on the non-stop, thrillingly choreographed action that made its predecessor so much fun.

title: God's Own Country
consensus: A quiet, moving rumination on loneliness and newfound intimacy,  marks an outstanding directorial debut for Francis Lee.

title: A Quiet Passion
consensus: offers a finely detailed portrait of a life whose placid passage may not have been inherently cinematic, but is made more affecting by Cynthia Nixon's strong performance.

title: Kedi
consensus: is a cat fancier's dream, but this thoughtful, beautifully filmed look at Istanbul's street feline population offers absorbing viewing for filmgoers of any purr-suasion.

title: Whose Streets?
consensus: takes a close-up look at the civil unrest that erupted after a shocking act of violence in Ferguson, Missouri - and the decades of simmering tension leading up to it.

title: The Florida Project
consensus: offers a colorfully empathetic look at an underrepresented part of the population that proves absorbing even as it raises sobering questions about modern America.

title: Truman
consensus: Well-written, well-acted, and patiently crafted,  takes an affecting look at a long friendship separated by distance but undimmed by time.

title: City of Ghosts
consensus: takes a hard-hitting, ground-level look at atrocities in a part of the world that may seem foreign to many viewers, but whose impact will be no less devastating.

title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette)
consensus: 's silly title and adorable characters belie a sober story whose colorful visuals delight the senses even as it braves dark emotional depths.

title: Blade Runner 2049
consensus: Visually stunning and narratively satisfying,  deepens and expands its predecessor's story while standing as an impressive filmmaking achievement in its own right.

title: The Salesman (Forushande)
consensus: takes an ambitiously complex look at thought-provoking themes, and the well-acted results prove another consistently absorbing entry in writer-director Asghar Farhadi's distinguished filmography.

title: Logan Lucky
consensus: High-octane fun that's smartly assembled without putting on airs,  marks a welcome end to Steven Soderbergh's retirement -- and proves he hasn't lost his ability to entertain.

title: War for the Planet of the Apes
consensus: combines breathtaking special effects and a powerful, poignant narrative to conclude this rebooted trilogy on a powerful -- and truly blockbuster -- note.

title: I Am Not Your Negro
consensus: offers an incendiary snapshot of James Baldwin's crucial observations on American race relations -- and a sobering reminder of how far we've yet to go.

title: Spider-Man: Homecoming
consensus: does whatever a second reboot can, delivering a colorful, fun adventure that fits snugly in the sprawling MCU without getting bogged down in franchise-building.

title: Hidden Figures
consensus: In heartwarming, crowd-pleasing fashion,  celebrates overlooked -- and crucial -- contributions from a pivotal moment in American history.

title: Baby Driver
consensus: Stylish, exciting, and fueled by a killer soundtrack,  hits the road and it's gone -- proving fast-paced action movies can be smartly written without sacrificing thrills.

title: The Big Sick
consensus: Funny, heartfelt, and intelligent,  uses its appealing leads and cross-cultural themes to prove the standard romcom formula still has some fresh angles left to explore.

title: Dunkirk
consensus: serves up emotionally satisfying spectacle, delivered by a writer-director in full command of his craft and brought to life by a gifted ensemble cast that honors the fact-based story.

title: Logan
consensus: Hugh Jackman makes the most of his final outing as Wolverine with a gritty, nuanced performance in a violent but surprisingly thoughtful superhero action film that defies genre conventions.

title: Wonder Woman
consensus: Thrilling, earnest, and buoyed by Gal Gadot's charismatic performance, Wonder Woman succeeds in spectacular fashion.

title: The Lego Batman Movie
consensus: continues its block-buster franchise's winning streak with another round of dizzyingly funny -- and beautifully animated -- family-friendly mayhem.
